content.text:
# Draft:Russian Empire-United States diplomatic missions

The Russian Empire and the United States both had an embassy and consulates in each others nations during their diplomatic relations. A few months after the Russian Empire fell during the February Revolution in 1917, the United States government began to pay the consuls' expenses at all seven locations because of the importance they were playing in assisting the large number of Russian emigrants coming to North America. On November 16, 1933, some of the consulates were closed after the signing of the Roosevelt-Litvinov agreement where the United States recognized the Soviet Union and diplomatic relations between the two countries began.
Russian posts in the US were in Chicago, Honolulu, New York (1810–), Philadelphia (1808–), Portland (1883–1901), San Francisco (1852–), Seattle (1914–), and Washington D.C..
US posts in Russia were in Archangelsk (1806–1809, 1811–1814), Batum (1890–), Helsingfors (1850–), Moscow (1861–), Odesa (1866–), Saint Petersburg (1803–), Petropavlovsk-Kamchatsky (1867–1873), Reval (1867–1870, 1910–), Riga (1824–1872, 1895–), Vladivostok and Warsaw (1875–).
Embassy
The Russian Empire Embassy was located in Washington, D.C. in Mrs. George Pullman House, while the United States Embassy was located in Saint Petersburg.
Russian Consulates
Russian Consular Agent Fortescue Whittle resided in Norfolk, entering into duty on 31 March 1810 as Russia's first consular agent in the USA. It is unknown when his term ended.
John Booker, an early agent of the United States in the Russian Empire, resided in Kronstadt during his appointment on 27 April 1805, entering duty the same day. Most other United States diplomatic missions to Russia have employed dedicated consulates or embassies.

Boston
The second ever Russian Consul to the United States, , resided in Boston. He was appointed 30 June 1808, entered duty on 24 August 1809, received exequatur on 2 September and served as the Russian Consul in Boston until 16 December 1826.
Charleston
An early consulate operated in Charleston.

Chicago
The consulate located in Chicago, Illinois was responsible for assisting Russian subjects and affairs in Illinois, Indiana, Iowa, Kansas, Kentucky, Michigan, Minnesota, Missouri, Nebraska, North Dakota, Ohio, Oklahoma, South Dakota, and Wisconsin.  The first consul was Paul von Thal, followed by Aron Albert von Schlippenbach from 9 September 1895 to May 1908, followed by Baron Ernest de Shilling from 1909 to 1912, followed by Victor Chihckine from 1912-1914, and finally Antoine Volkoff who served as consul general from 1914 until November 16, 1933, which is when the Roosevelt-Litvinov agreement was signed where the United States recognized the Soviet Union and diplomatic relations between the two countries began. The Czar's picture had already been removed in 1928.
Honolulu
The consulate located in Honolulu, Hawaii was responsible for assisting Russian subjects and affairs in Hawaii, and was under the jurisdiction of the San Francisco Consulate. Imperial Russian Vice Consul in Honolulu were J.C. Pflueger from 1862-1872, J.W. Pflueger from 1872-1886, J.F. Hackfeld from 1886-1900, I.A. Isenberg from 1900-1904, and F.A. Klamp from 1904-1907. Consular officials continued to operate in Honolulu even after the October Revolution.
New Orleans
Russian Vice-consul Beverly Chew resided in New Orleans. He entered duty in February 1811, received exequatur on 24 July 1812 and served until June 1812.
New York
Many Russian emigrants that came to the United States between 1903-1926 came thru New York, making the New York consulate an important part of the Russian Empire's diplomatic mission. At one point the consulate was located in the The Flatiron Building.
Philadelphia
Philadelphia was the residence of the first Russian Minister to the United States. The consulate located in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania was responsible for assisting Russian subjects and affairs in Pennsylvania, and was under the jurisdiction of the New York Consulate until 1915 when responsibility was assumed by the consul general in Pittsburgh. In 1816, the consul general Kosloff was arrested and was released later that year in November.  In 1895, Imperial Russian Vice Consul William H. Tucker, an American citizen and prominent member of the Philadelphia Board of Trade, was appointed and in 1912 he was named full consul. Consular officials continued to operate in Philadelphia even after the October Revolution.

Portland, Maine
Russian Consular Agent Ebenezer Mayo resided in Portland, Maine, entering duty on 3 May 1812.
Portland, Oregon
The consulate located in Portland, Oregon was responsible for assisting Russian subjects and affairs in Oregon, and was under the jurisdiction of the San Francisco Consulate.  It was headed by Imperial Russian Vice Consul Gustav Wilson, a Finnish-born American citizen who was appointed in 1883 and served until 1901.  The Portland consulate was closed after Wilson's resignation in 1901, and records were moved to the San Francisco Consulate. Consular officials continued to operate in Portland even after the October Revolution.
Providence
Samuel Snow served as Russian consular agent in Providence, entering duty on 10 April 1812.
Salem
John Prince, Jr. served as Russian consular agent in Salem, entering duty on 13 April 1812.
San Francisco
On February 14, 1852, due to increased activity of the Russian-American Company in California, the government of the Russian Empire appointed entrepreneur William Montgomery Stuart as its first consul in San Francisco.  The consulate in San Francisco, California was responsible for Russian subjects and affairs in Arizona, California, Colorado, Idaho, Montana, Nevada, New Mexico, Oregon, Utah, Washington, Wyoming, Hawaii and Alaska.
Savannah
William Scarbrough served as Russian consular agent in Savannah, entering duty on March 1811.
Seattle
The consulate in Seattle, Washington was responsible for assisting Russian subjects and affairs in Washington, Oregon, Idaho, Montana, and Alaska, and was under the jurisdiction of the San Francisco Consulate.  It was closed on November 16, 1933, which is when the Roosevelt-Litvinov agreement was signed where the United States recognized the Soviet Union and diplomatic relations between the two countries began.
American Consulates
John Booker, an early agent of the United States in the Russian Empire, resided in Kronstadt during his appointment on 27 April 1805, entering duty the same day. Most other United States diplomatic missions to Russia have employed dedicated consulates or embassies.
Arkhangelsk
The consulate in Arkhangelsk operated from 1806 to 1809, and again from 1811 to 1814.

Odesa
The consulate in Odesa operated from 1830 to 1918.
Petropavlovsk

Saint Petersburg
The consulate provided assistance to Russian and American citizens in Northwestern Russia. It was active from 1865.
Vladivostok
The consulate in Vladivostok was opened in 1875, later headed by a commercial agent. In 1898, U.S. Ambassador Hitchcock prompted the United States Congress to appropriate the supplies for an American consulate in Vladivostok because of the American trade with Siberia, seeking to increase trade by promoting direct shipping routes. It was subsequently closed after the Soviet Revolution in 1923.  The consulate provided assistance to Russian and American citizens in the Far East and in Eastern Siberia.
Warsaw
The Consulate in Warsaw operated from 1875 on.
